description.plain:
Fall Out Boy is an American rock band hailing from Wilmette, Illinois. The band was formed in 2001 by Pete Wentz, who supplies bass and lyrics to the band, and guitarist Joe Trohman, who both used to be part of metalcore band Arma Angelus. Trohman later recruited vocalist Patrick Stump, who initially tried out as the band’s drummer, after meeting him in a bookstore. After the release of Project Rocket/Fall Out Boy, a split EP with Project Rocket. It was recorded without current drummer Andy Hurley due to him being disinterested in the project; Hurley later joined in 2003 as a replacement touring drummer.

Fueled By Ramen, who were a small independent label at the time, personally called Fall Out Boy to ask them to record a full-length record after hearing one of their demos online. This album became their 2003 debut, Take This To Your Grave, and was a tipping point between the band’s underground success to success in the mainstream. It was the band’s last album to feature Stump as the lead lyricist.

The band’s 2004 acoustic EP, My Heart Will Always Be the B-Side to My Tongue, became their first charting release and gave fans a taste of what to expect on their sophomore album From Under The Cork Tree. The album creation was set back in February 2005 after Wentz’s suicide attempt, which influenced songs such as “7 Minutes In Heaven (Atavan Halen).” The album was released in May 2005 through Island Records, featuring guest vocals from William Beckett of The Academy Is… and Brendon Urie of Panic! At The Disco.

2007’s Infinity On High saw the band subtly separate themselves from the pop-punk sound they were known for, featuring unexpected guests like rapper Jay-Z. The album was a huge mainstream success, being certified platinum in six countries and cementing Fall Out Boy as one of the biggest pop-punk bands of the time.

The band continued on their experimental tangent for their 2008 LP Folie à Deux, breaking away almost entirely from their pop-punk sound. The group had a lengthy promotion process, which included the release of mixtape CitizensFOB: Welcome To The New Administration. Lyrically focusing mainly on themes like decaying relationships and fame, the album received a mixed response from fans and critics.

In 2009, the band announced a hiatus to allow the members to focus on their own projects. Among other things, this break spawned Stump’s solo album Soul Punk, Wentz’s EDM project Black Cards, and Trohman and Hurley’s band The Damned Things.

2013’s Save Rock & Roll was recorded entirely in secret, and the group’s reformation only became apparent after the release of their lead single “My Song’s Know What You Did In The Dark (Light Em Up).” The record generally received positive reviews, and featured several all-star guests, including Elton John and Courtney Love. 2013 also saw the release of PAX AM Days, a punk-influenced EP that is described as the antithesis of Save Rock & Roll.

The 2015 release of American Beauty/American Psycho saw the band continue to push for a radio-friendly sound, while also experimenting with samples on many tracks. The single “Immortals”, appeared on the soundtrack of Disney’s Big Hero 6. The band later released Make America Psycho Again,, a rap remix album of American Beauty/American Psycho that disappointed both fans and critics.

The band’s seventh studio album, M A  N   I    A, was first teased in early 2017. It was initially slated for a September 2017 release, and early singles such as “Young and Menace” demonstrated an almost complete pull-away from their previous rock-influenced music for a more EDM inspired sound. The release date was subsequently pushed back to January after almost-completely scrapping of the material for the album. The album was shortly followed up with a limited demo EP titled LLAMANIA, which has been teased in the music video for “Wilson (Expensive Mistakes)”. The EP consisted of demo tracks that were scrapped from M A  N   I    A.

Before the band’s major project, “The MANIA Experience,” had taken into effect, Pete announced that a three-tracked EP would be released. This would include a studio version of the 2008 mixtape demo from “Welcome to the New Administration,” Lake Effect Kid, a semi-new song and a really new song. On August 22, a surprise proclamation had appeared in the band’s social media, stating that the Lake Effect Kid EP was going to be released at midnight. In its release, every song was heavily influenced by Chicago, the band’s hometown.

songs.full_title: Sugar, We're Goin Down by Fall Out Boy

annotatable.link_title: Sugar, We’re Goin Down by Fall Out Boy
annotatable.title: Sugar, We're Goin Down

body.plain:
“Sugar, We’re Goin Down” was released in April 2005 as the lead single from Fall Out Boy’s second studio album, From Under the Cork Tree. As their first top ten hit, the song is often credited as being the catalyst for the band entering the mainstream where they were exposed to a new audience.

Fall Out Boy bassist Pete Wentz wrote the lyrics. In 2006, he told Rolling Stone magazine:

I wrote the lyrics in Chicago. I was with my dad, and we were listening to the old music where they’d always say ‘sugar’ and ‘honey’ – stuff like that. I was like, ‘Why doesn’t anyone do that anymore?’ Be we really locked it down in California."

The lyrics in the song’s chorus were intentionally slurred by vocalist Patrick Stump who told Rolling Stone that he was:

trying to do a straight punk song for fun… I saw those lyrics and just kind of barked them out. But there was something about the rhythm of it, where I was like, ‘Hmm, that actually might be too good for just a shitty punk song.

In the now iconic music video, the viewer follows a socially outcast boy with antlers played by Donald Cummings of The Virgins. Throughout, the boy is persecuted by the father of the girl he develops feelings for, and attempts to remove his antlers in hope of social acceptance. After discovering that the father has hooves, they’re able to connect through a mutual acceptance for each other.



Fall Out Boy later sampled the song in “What a Catch, Donnie” on their 2008 album, Folie à Deux. The same antlers can be seen in the music video. From the album of the same name, “Save Rock and Roll” also includes a reference to the song.

“Sugar, We’re Goin Down” went on to become Fall Out Boy’s first two-million seller in July 2009.

songs.full_title: Centuries by Fall Out Boy

annotatable.link_title: Centuries by Fall Out Boy
annotatable.title: Centuries

body.plain:
“Centuries” is the lead single from from Fall Out Boy’s sixth studio album. It’s a grandiose track about the fight to make a lasting artistic impression.

In an interview, Pete Wentz explains:


Our band came from the suburbs of Chicago. The blandest place. Nothing comes out of there, no one would have ever said that a rock band would come out of there and go on to play arenas. ‘Centuries’ goes back to that David versus Goliath idea. Even U2 had to start somewhere…

Change terrifies a lot of us. ‘Centuries’ really bangs on that. It’s like, just because you’re being told that what you’re doing sucks, that you’re weird or whatever, that doesn’t mean that you’re not a leader, creating something new. Leaders attract a lot of arrows, you know?


The annotations on this page were made by bassist Pete Wentz, as confirmed in a tweet by him:

https://twitter.com/petewentz/status/510306316674277376

songs.full_title: Uma Thurman by Fall Out Boy

annotatable.link_title: Uma Thurman by Fall Out Boy
annotatable.title: Uma Thurman

body.plain:
“Uma Thurman” was the lead single from Fall Out Boy’s 2015 album American Beauty/American Psycho. The song became a major hit for the band, appearing on both the Billboard Rock and Pop charts. It samples The Munsters opening theme, and evokes the star of another work famed by a surf rock theme, Pulp Fiction.

Fall Out Boy explained the song to their fans on Facebook:

Uma Thurman and Winona Ryder, they were these women in pop culture who were quirky, but that made me only crush on them harder. and rather than going with the traditional Uma Thurman role, we thought a lot about Kill Bill and who her character was in that, and this kind of resilience and this violence, but there’s something that’s authentic about it (like a woman taking revenge or being empowered). So that’s what the chorus of the song’s about, and the verses are what you would do to try and capture this woman’s affection.

songs.full_title: Thnks fr th Mmrs by Fall Out Boy

annotatable.link_title: Thnks fr th Mmrs by Fall Out Boy
annotatable.title: Thnks fr th Mmrs

body.plain:
One of Fall Out Boy’s now classic songs, “Thnks fr th Mmrs” tells the tale of doomed lovers who are still in it for the sex. The third single from their third album, Infinity on High, the song went on to be one of their bigger hits at the time, peaking at #11 on the Hot 100 (interestingly enough, it peaked on the date 7/7/2007).

Almost as notable as the song was the music video, which featured both chimpanzees (who were a bit dangerous) and Kim Kardashian, who was a fan of the band. Bassist Pete Wentz later described it as “insane,” and singer Patrick Stump said that it was a terrible idea to work with chimps. The video also touched on the absurdity of fame that the newly-popular band was faced with, which itself was one of the larger themes of Infinity on High.

In an interview with NME, Stump mentioned that the band have “grown into the song” since its release and was very much encouraged to “go big” on its recording by producer Babyface.

description_annotation.fragment: The Last of the Real Ones

body.plain:
“The Last of the Real Ones” is a love song that uses celestial imagery to illustrate the gravity of the narrator’s devotion.  It is the third single and second track from Fall Out Boy’s upcoming seventh album, M A  N   I    A. The single was released one month after the band announced that the album would be delayed, and it was written the week after the announcement.
https://twitter.com/PatrickStump/status/893184837854654464

The music video is a direct continuation of “Young and Menace”, and appears to share many similarities to the music video for Kanye West’s 2007 single “Flashing Lights”. It was later revealed in an interview with The Charlotte Observer that these similarities were intentional.

body.plain:
After a four year hiatus, Fall Out Boy returns. The song is about their return to music and starting with a clean slate. A burned slate.

This is the first single off their fifth album, Save Rock and Roll.

A previous version of this song was released on their website as a demo in 2003 with very different lyrics, but a similar theme.

annotatable.title: Stay Frosty Royal Milk Tea

body.plain:
“Stay Frosty Royal Milk Tea” is the opening track on M A  N   I    A.

In the song, themes of celebrity culture and madness spawning from that culture are brought up, introducing the audience to ideas that are revisited throughout the album.

The title of the song is a reference to the two llamas that are seen throughout the Mania era, Frosty and Royal-Tea.



Frosty (left) and Royal-Tea (right)

songs.full_title: Wilson (Expensive Mistakes) by Fall Out Boy

annotatable.link_title: Wilson (Expensive Mistakes) by Fall Out Boy
annotatable.title: Wilson (Expensive Mistakes)

body.plain:
This song was premiered on tour in Cleveland, Ohio. Fans suspected that it would be the fourth single to be released from M A N I A, but it was later announced that “Hold Me Tight Or Don’t” would be released as the fourth single instead. “Wilson (Expensive Mistakes)” was eventually released as the fifth single from the album on Jan. 11, 2018.

The title is a reference to the 2000 film “Cast Away” starring Tom Hanks, in which the main character, FedEx employee Chuck Noland, ends up stranded on an island after a plane crash. One of the packages from the plane contains a Wilson volleyball. After leaving a bloody hand print on it, Chuck draws a face and names this volleyball Wilson. It serves as his only companion during his time on the island.

The music video was set to be released on January 12th, one week before the release of the album, but it was later announced via an Instagram post that the release date had been moved forward one day to the 11th. The post also teased the video, featuring Pete Wentz wearing the outfit he had previously worn in The Youngblood Chronicles, a series of 11 music videos for the album Save Rock and Roll which told one cohesive story. The music video itself contains many references to past music videos in the form of products being sold in an infomercial or on a home shopping channel. The number that appeared throughout the music video, “1-833-OUT-BOYS”, lead fans to an audio message spoken by Patrick Stump.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wH-by1ydBTM

songs.full_title: Young and Menace by Fall Out Boy

annotatable.link_title: Young and Menace by Fall Out Boy
annotatable.title: Young and Menace

body.plain:
“Young And Menace” is the lead single from Fall Out Boy’s seventh studio record, Mania. According to bassist Pete Wentz, it is one of the weirdest songs the band has ever made. He says it is about feeling like an outsider in his own community, and finding people like himself through punk-rock music. The lyrics also seem to reference Fall Out Boy’s history as a unit.

A music video was released to accompany the song. One article described it as a ‘trippy, nightmarish look at domestic violence’ that depicts a small child being chased by llama-like monsters, and eventually getting lost in a place where no one can understand their language. At the end, it is revealed that the whole thing was, in fact, a dream, and the ‘monsters’ are the child’s abusive parents. The video carries the same theme of being an outsider that the song does.

The video’s description features a message from Pete himself; a short paragraph that he also posted on the Fall Out Boy Twitter.

The gentle pull of a tide that rolls over and over again and by the sheer nature of its essence it becomes an indestructible will- ripping out sand- eroding what was before it- without a care… a transformational monster-becoming the madness and frenzy of a truly bulletproof wave. I’m not just here for your love, I’m here for all of the love. An overdose of dopamine- we are living inside of MANIA right now. the never sleeping, never blinking- caught forever in the sunshine riptide. -pw

annotatable.title: The Kids Aren't Alright

body.plain:
“The Kids Aren’t Alright” is the fifth track from Fall Out Boy’s sixth studio album American Beauty/American Psycho.

The song title is an allusion to “The Kids Are Alright,” a 1966 song by The Who.



The title was used for a Who documentary and a 2010 movie about a lesbian couple (although they spelled it “All Right”).



And, of course, The Offspring invented the title back in ‘98.

songs.full_title: The Phoenix by Fall Out Boy

annotatable.link_title: The Phoenix by Fall Out Boy
annotatable.title: The Phoenix

body.plain:
OVERVIEW

“The Phoenix” is the opening track on Fall Out Boy’s comeback album Save Rock and Roll. Many interpret the song to be the band’s statement regarding the end of their hiatus: they started it because they felt “burnt out”, but now they rise out of these ashes like a phoenix.

The song is unique in that it is the only Fall Out Boy song that premiered with its music video – up until the point of its release, fans had never heard the song. This was done to help promote the start of the Young Blood Chronicles, a series of videos based on each song from the record.

The song features the London Symphony Orchestra in the intense background of the song. This background was suggested by Patrick Stump, who had been influenced by the sound of the fourth movement of Dmitri Shostakovich’s “Leningrad” symphony:
http://youtu.be/Xbru9UcCLQQ?t=1h6m8s

RECEPTION

“The Phoenix” was well received by fans, which caused Fall Out Boy to use the song as the opener for the “Save Rock and Roll” tour as well as “Monumentour”. It peaked at #80 on the Billboard Hot 100 and appeared on other charts. In the UK, it topped the “Rock and Metal” chart.

SINGLE



MUSIC VIDEO

http://youtu.be/5hDZbroaQDc?t=13s

NOTABLE LIVE PERFORMANCES

[As the opener to the Save Rock and Roll tour]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_JWsMorK1cE
The band wore masks as a nod to the song “Car Radio” by tour mates Twenty-One Pilots.

Victoria’s Secret Fashion Show

USES IN POPULAR CULTURE

The song features in the Gameplay Trailer of WWE 2K14, the first WWE game released under the 2K label.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D99l1aGJCtA

songs.full_title: Champion by Fall Out Boy

annotatable.link_title: Champion by Fall Out Boy
annotatable.title: Champion

body.plain:
“Champion” is the second single from Fall Out Boy’s 2017’s release MANIA. The song was released on June 23, 2017. While the band’s first comeback tune ‘Young And Menace’ seemed to suggest they were moving in a more electronic direction, Champion is closer to what the Chicagoan chart-toppers are known for: Alternative pop with powerful lyrics.

When the song was released, a message from Pete Wentz was posted on Fall Out Boy’s social media pages, stating:



Nelson Mandela. Billie Jean King. The kid hunters of the purple buffalo. Niki Lauda. Jamal Malik. Michael Jordan playing baseball. The Warriors (and the Cubs!)… In my head champions aren’t born, they are forged… -PW

Champion was first hinted at in a tweet on the 15th of June, and the song’s title and release date — the 22nd — were later confirmed when the band shared this image with their fans:

http://twitter.com/falloutboy/status/876867574633566212

This was followed by a trailer, featuring scenes of people on skateboards and teasing a snippet of the song. The ‘visualiser’ music video that was released alongside the song stayed in a similar vein and featured the same llama characters from the Young And Menace video.

On December 15th of 2017, the band collaborated with RM of BTS to create a remix of the song.

songs.full_title: Dance, Dance by Fall Out Boy

annotatable.link_title: Dance, Dance by Fall Out Boy
annotatable.title: Dance, Dance

body.plain:
“Dance, Dance” details a teenager’s obsession with a particular girl and his desperation to do anything to sleep with her. It follows his obsession from his awkward initial attraction to a chance meeting with her at a school dance wherein he presumably gets to dance with her.

Following their massive breakout single “Sugar, We’re Going Down”, it was probable that “Dance, Dance” would become a massive hit, especially with its superiority to the first single. (Just ask Patrick Stump!)

https://twitter.com/patrickstump/status/391328695824027648

Of course, it was a massive success, hitting nine on the Hot 100 and becoming Fall Out Boy’s second top ten.

songs.full_title: Church by Fall Out Boy

annotatable.link_title: Church by Fall Out Boy
annotatable.title: Church

body.plain:
“Church” is an epic love anthem featuring strong religious imagery, particularly that of Christianity,  as metaphors for worship in terms of a romantic relationship, as well as its connection to a more spiritual one. To service this, the track also features prevalent samples of a pipe organ, large church choir and cathedral bells.

These themes continue into the next track: “Heaven’s Gate.”

Patrick Stump revealed in an interview with Rolling Stone that the song originally had a different vocal melody and lyrics.

songs.full_title: Alone Together by Fall Out Boy

annotatable.link_title: Alone Together by Fall Out Boy
annotatable.title: Alone Together

body.plain:
This song is about a relationship that may or may not have been supposed to happen. The two appear to be different but are actually quite the same.

Notice the juxtaposition in the title of the phrase being ‘alone together’ so, in fact, the two are not alone.

Pete has been known to mention in concert how no matter how lonely we get, music will always be there for us.



“Alone Together” was released as the band’s third overall single from Save Rock and Roll and was later certified platinum by the RIAA.

annotatable.link_title: Immortals by Fall Out Boy
annotatable.title: Immortals

body.plain: The 10th track of American Beauty/American Psycho, “Immortals” first appeared on the soundtrack for the 2014 Disney animated comedy superhero film Big Hero 6. Fall Out Boy was asked to create the song after learning about the movie’s plot in which a young boy loses his older brother to a super-villain. He recovers from his grief by assembling a team of super-heroes, including a robot created by his deceased brother, to apprehend the villain.

songs.full_title: Heaven's Gate by Fall Out Boy

annotatable.link_title: Heaven’s Gate by Fall Out Boy
annotatable.title: Heaven's Gate

body.plain:
In an interview with Music Choice, Patrick mentioned how this song “felt really natural to all of [them]” and came together easily, even though it doesn’t sound all that typical of the band.

One interpretation of this song is as a kind of dialogue between a couple, where the narrator is tired of the world, of struggling, iniquity, and chasing frivolous things and calls out saying that although the narrator doesn’t believe they can make it to heaven alone, they still wish they could and is calling on their lover to help them.

annotatable.link_title: 20 Dollar Nose Bleed by Fall Out Boy (Ft. Brendon Urie)
annotatable.title: 20 Dollar Nose Bleed

body.plain:
The song name refers to the drug mentioned in it – Benzedrine, a form of amphetamine known to cause nosebleeds.



Around the time of this song’s release it was sold for about $20, hence the title.

album.full_title: Folie à Deux by Fall Out Boy
album.name: Folie à Deux

annotatable.link_title: Fall Out Boy
annotatable.title: Fall Out Boy

body.plain:
Fall Out Boy is an American rock band hailing from Wilmette, Illinois. The band was formed in 2001 by Pete Wentz, who supplies bass and lyrics to the band, and guitarist Joe Trohman, who both used to be part of metalcore band Arma Angelus. Trohman later recruited vocalist Patrick Stump, who initially tried out as the band’s drummer, after meeting him in a bookstore. After the release of Project Rocket/Fall Out Boy, a split EP with Project Rocket. It was recorded without current drummer Andy Hurley due to him being disinterested in the project; Hurley later joined in 2003 as a replacement touring drummer.

Fueled By Ramen, who were a small independent label at the time, personally called Fall Out Boy to ask them to record a full-length record after hearing one of their demos online. This album became their 2003 debut, Take This To Your Grave, and was a tipping point between the band’s underground success to success in the mainstream. It was the band’s last album to feature Stump as the lead lyricist.

The band’s 2004 acoustic EP, My Heart Will Always Be the B-Side to My Tongue, became their first charting release and gave fans a taste of what to expect on their sophomore album From Under The Cork Tree. The album creation was set back in February 2005 after Wentz’s suicide attempt, which influenced songs such as “7 Minutes In Heaven (Atavan Halen).” The album was released in May 2005 through Island Records, featuring guest vocals from William Beckett of The Academy Is… and Brendon Urie of Panic! At The Disco.

2007’s Infinity On High saw the band subtly separate themselves from the pop-punk sound they were known for, featuring unexpected guests like rapper Jay-Z. The album was a huge mainstream success, being certified platinum in six countries and cementing Fall Out Boy as one of the biggest pop-punk bands of the time.

The band continued on their experimental tangent for their 2008 LP Folie à Deux, breaking away almost entirely from their pop-punk sound. The group had a lengthy promotion process, which included the release of mixtape CitizensFOB: Welcome To The New Administration. Lyrically focusing mainly on themes like decaying relationships and fame, the album received a mixed response from fans and critics.

In 2009, the band announced a hiatus to allow the members to focus on their own projects. Among other things, this break spawned Stump’s solo album Soul Punk, Wentz’s EDM project Black Cards, and Trohman and Hurley’s band The Damned Things.

2013’s Save Rock & Roll was recorded entirely in secret, and the group’s reformation only became apparent after the release of their lead single “My Song’s Know What You Did In The Dark (Light Em Up).” The record generally received positive reviews, and featured several all-star guests, including Elton John and Courtney Love. 2013 also saw the release of PAX AM Days, a punk-influenced EP that is described as the antithesis of Save Rock & Roll.

The 2015 release of American Beauty/American Psycho saw the band continue to push for a radio-friendly sound, while also experimenting with samples on many tracks. The single “Immortals”, appeared on the soundtrack of Disney’s Big Hero 6. The band later released Make America Psycho Again,, a rap remix album of American Beauty/American Psycho that disappointed both fans and critics.

The band’s seventh studio album, M A  N   I    A, was first teased in early 2017. It was initially slated for a September 2017 release, and early singles such as “Young and Menace” demonstrated an almost complete pull-away from their previous rock-influenced music for a more EDM inspired sound. The release date was subsequently pushed back to January after almost-completely scrapping of the material for the album. The album was shortly followed up with a limited demo EP titled LLAMANIA, which has been teased in the music video for “Wilson (Expensive Mistakes)”. The EP consisted of demo tracks that were scrapped from M A  N   I    A.

Before the band’s major project, “The MANIA Experience,” had taken into effect, Pete announced that a three-tracked EP would be released. This would include a studio version of the 2008 mixtape demo from “Welcome to the New Administration,” Lake Effect Kid, a semi-new song and a really new song. On August 22, a surprise proclamation had appeared in the band’s social media, stating that the Lake Effect Kid EP was going to be released at midnight. In its release, every song was heavily influenced by Chicago, the band’s hometown.

name: Fall Out Boy
